lg.l: Picking wild convolvuli Wild convolvuli. Pōhue, an indigenous bindweed, which produces white flowers during the summer.
Under a December sky,
Sheltered from the sun and breeze
By umbrageous tangled trees,
While with crisp and sparkling motion
Laps against the rocks the ocean,
And the cattle white and dun
Chew the cud out in the sun
Lying midst the fern and clover,
Which the shadows travel over
Of the fleecy clouds that fly
Thro’ the azure summer sky,
While the Billow mountains Billow mountains. The location of the reference is unclear.
Rise like frozen billows blue
Lowering in the sun north-west
Each one tipt with silver crest
Over head the parakeets Parakeets. Kākāriki, or the New Zealand parakeet, is predominantly bright green, with different species distinguished by coloured areas on their heads.
Sail along in emerald fleets
Speeding swiftly thro’ the air
After berries ripe and fair;—
Now upon the boughs alight
In the sunshine warm and bright
Chatter to the breeze and sun
As along the boughs they run
While the little girl and boy
Crow and caper in their joy
And the merry cicadae Cicadae. Dozens of species and subspecies of cicada are unique to Aotearoa New Zealand.
Chirrup upon tuft and tree.

body.p: Orepuki, Orepuki. A small Māori settlement in the south of the South Island, which had attracted settlers after the discovery of gold in 1865. Dec. 31st, 1878.
